Elli Hu
I listen to music, then I write about it. @NYULocal
Apr 6

Meet NYU Collaborative Project The Violet Collective

Comprised of Connor Gatesman (Gotzman), Marcus Harley (Swami), Yunil Jeon (3:43), Jordan Taylor (akari), and Pedro Cañas (Pedro.), the “Violet Collective” is a newly formed collaborative music project at NYU. Their first show will be on April 7th at Muchmore’s. Tickets are available online, as well as at the door. The show will begin at 6:30, ending around 8:30. Before Friday’s show, we met up with the Collective and got some insight into who they are.

Local: What is the “Violet Collective”, and how did it form?

Pedro.: So Marcus and I were actually recording an intro for class. I was a first-semester freshman at the time, Marcus is was a sophomore. We started looking at each other’s computers and saw Ableton Live up, and I was like: “Oh, what are you doing in Ableton Live?” And he was like, “Oh dude, I do some sampling and stuff like that.” It’s basically the concept of taking instrumentals, and composing a new track. So, he [Marcus] really influenced me on that part. I started vibing with that, before I was more of a DJ, producing electronic music. I guess the “Violet Collective” sort of sprung from there. We were like, “what if we made a group?” So then, I got in touch with JT [akari] again- we had met before coming to NYU. We actually DJ-ed at some guy’s birthday party, so we met there.
Gotzman: So I’m more of a DJ-more of a turntablist, dealing with more hip-hop. But I produce a bit. I met Pedro though music business — 
Pedro.: We just sorta vibed and were like: “Hey, let’s form this group at NYU, to just sample and make music.” That’s how Yunil [3:43] got involved as well.
Swami: I met Connor when Pedro and I were actually working on a track I was sampling. Connor just came through and showed us his stuff, and we were freestyling in Steinhardt — in the room where we had our intro class. We were just vibing so hard, it was such a good night. Pedro came up with the “Violet Collective,” we just wanted to start putting stuff out as a group. We all were down for it, to put our stuff out under one name. “Violet Collective,” NYU Violets, shows our pride, and also the collectivism behind our artistic styles. I didn’t know that I influenced Pedro to start sampling, I think that’s pretty cool. In intro class, I would just show him my stuff. He was one of the first people to listen to my stuff and be like: “Yo, this is cool,” and he would show me his stuff. We were collabing in class, it was just so fun talking over the professor and being like: “I’m doing this — that’s nice.” During our breaks, we would take pictures and talk to the professor. It was some good times, I’m glad I met him.
Pedro.: We starting taking pictures and were jokingly saying, “This’ll be our mixtape in a couple years.”

Local: How did each of you get into music?
Swami: I started making music when I started here. I didn’t even know how to use Ableton until I started producing out of curiosity. Before that, I had one or two music classes in high school. I played bass in my junior and senior year for a band talent show, and outside of that, I’ve had no formal music training. The curiosity pushes me to make a lot of stuff, it’s why I’m still doing it, while having a lot of fun expressing myself.
akari: I started producing when I was 15. I saw a beatmaking video on YouTube and was like: “Oh, that’s cool. I’ll try it out.” That’s how I got into things when I was younger. I started producing on Fruity Loops — it was really bad for a long time. One of my friends in school, he kind of rapped but didn’t really. We became really close friends and started actually working on tracks, that’s when I started taking producing seriously. Before that, I didn’t really have any experience with music. It was like, “Oh, I listen to it.”
Gotzman: Musically, I played violin for 8 years, and I got tired of that. I initially got into production when I started DJ-ing in middle school. I started finding out about people like DJ Shadow and Cut Chemist, so I got really into turntablism. A lot of that is rooted in sampling, so I started finding out about people who sampled — like Nujabes. I started crate-digging in Pittsburgh, where I’m from, and then I basically took what inspired me and, using Logic, started messing around.
Pedro.: I also started in middle school, I was in a tech class in 8th grade. I wasn’t supposed to be listening to music, but the teacher was on the other side of the classroom and I had my earphones in. I was playing Minecraft, and all of the sudden I’m on YouTube looking up Minecraft videos. I hear a Deadmau5 mix out of nowhere, so I looked up this Deadmau5 guy — I used to call him “Deadmau-five” because I couldn’t understand how to pronounce his name. He was playing at a mall with his mouse helmet, and I guess that’s when I started vibing with electronic music. From there I started listening to Armin Van Buuren — a big trance DJ. He used to do A State of Trance at MSG, from then on, I said I wanted to start making electronic music.

Local: How do your individual backgrounds impact your dynamic as a collective?
Pedro.: As a collective, I definitely reached out to these guys because I knew they were pretty ambitious and persistent in what they do. JT [akari] for the most part — actually no, JT is the most persistent artist I know. Whenever I ask, “Hey, do you have a new release or something to bring into the collective?” He always says: “Yeah, I’m on it. I already have a track.” It usually takes me more time. As a collective, we all bring different things to the playing field, but essentially, we’re all just trying to figure out who we are and express ourselves.
Swami: I’m pretty secretive about my music. If you ask me about it, I kind of wouldn’t say anything. But on the low, I always have something. I just have a repertoire of things that I’ve made. But really it’s a matter of: “Do I want to put this music out yet? Am I ready for it to be heard? Do I want to be heard?” It’s really a personal thing — all my music is personal. My current project is really personal, but it’s so chill. Those that have listened to it so far have really liked it, they vibe to it. I’m excited to perform it on Friday.
Pedro.: Adding onto that, I think a major aspect of what the “Violet Collective” is, is a space to experiment and express ourselves differently. Like, we all have our own SoundCloud pages, but the things I put up on the “Violet Collective,” I normally wouldn’t put up on my main SoundCloud account. I’m trying to market myself as a deep-house page, not sample-based music.
Swami: The goal is expression, how we put together our own styles to form this unit. It’s really coming along, we’re finding themes between our projects in each volume. Soon, it’ll be totally solid and you’ll hear it, and know that it’s us.
Pedro.: In terms of what makes us more diverse than any other collective at NYU — 
Swami: We have black people. *laughs*
Pedro.: At our events, we have so many ideas to create themes in the context of live concerts. I don’t want to spoil anything, but Friday’s show is going to be pretty interactive. I’m really looking forward to the event, and hope we’ll see a lot of people there.

Local: What are your individual processes, and how does this translate into your collaborative work?
Swami: For the most part, JT [akari], Pedro, and I, use Ableton. Our familiarity with it is what makes it easy for us to work together. I think collaboratively, we just do it well. We just chill in Pedro’s room, bump on his speakers, and mix together. It’s not one person calling the shots, we’ll give each other mixes that we’ve made and sit there and make comments: “You should probably boost this, EQ this, add a compressor here, make this effect…” The collaboration is in each of us making the calls. As far as composition goes, we haven’t really composed anything together yet, but hopefully we’ll do that soon.
akari: A lot of my music is sample-based. Recently, I’ve been experimenting with different genres — more electronic stuff and weird sounds. I’m trying to find a way to incorporate that into sampling. 
Gotzman: I like to get all my samples off of records. I’ll go to a record store and find like a, “How to Cha-Cha” record. I’ll cut it up and see if I find anything. For me, it’s all about repurposing stuff that was never meant to be used in that context.

Local: What do you hope to achieve as a collective?
Gotzman: World dominance.
Swami: Recognition, identification, character.

Local: So I should be able to listen to a volume, and realize: “Shit, that’s the ‘Violet Collective’”
Pedro.: As a collective, I think a goal is to have a million faces, and violets everywhere. You won’t be able to see us — 
Gotzman: — Like a prairie.
Pedro.: We’ll just have flowers everywhere, violets all over the place.
Swami: Like 21 Savage in that video, where he’s doing “Skrtt Skrtt” in this totally ambient, vaporwave scene.

Local: What should listeners expect at Friday’s show?
Pedro: Honestly, that’s up to these guys [akari and Swami]. I don’t even know what I’m gonna be seeing.
Gotzman: Yeah, I don’t know either.
Swami: Yeah, I’m gonna rap. I have raps for each song that I’m gonna perform, and some mixes thrown in there too. I’m working on the mix right now — I was actually mixing right before this. I’m pretty nervous, this is my third performance, but my friend JP is going to be with me. I hope he gets there on time, we’ve been talking about it — the tape that we did together, the current project, is us. So Master Swami is me and him. I’m Swami Sounds when I’m producing, Master Swami when I’m part of a collective effort. I’m just Swami in general. JP and I are just gonna be spitting on the stuff I made, I love the beats I made for it. I hope people get the vibe I go for, loud and clear.
akari: I’m probably just going to be doing my beats. Most of it is going to be chiller, hoping people will just vibe out. I have some turnup stuff, might rap a little bit, never know.
Pedro.: Also shout out Adrien Calvet and Selva. They’re gonna be doing back-to-back DJ house sets. Adrien actually goes to NYU, we hope to have him in some “Violet Collective” stuff soon. He isn’t part of the Collective yet, we’re pulling him in for the show first. It’s gonna be really cool to see what he has in store. Selva is friends with Adrien, the two of them are gonna start the show.
Gotzman: Yeah, a lot of good music.

Local: So what’s next? Does the collective have any other plans in motion before the end of the semester?
Pedro.: Other than finishing, secretively, we’re teaming up with a clothing brand at NYU. Can’t really talk about names yet but we’re meeting up soon. We’re also going to start doing Boiler Rooms too, have them available on Facebook Live, as well as on a friend’s internet radio. As a future goal, as a “Violet Collective,” I want to be seen as more of a team. I want people to know our names, our themes, and have people understand that we’re going to be a community.

Local: To clarify, are you looking to expand beyond music? Are you trying to develop into an visual and musical arts collective?
Pedro.: As of now, just music — 
Swami.: — Music is the core.
Pedro.: Yeah, but we’re limitless.

Local: So if someone wanted to get involved with the Collective, how can they reach out?
Pedro.: Please just contact us, we’re trying to build a team.
